content.question: Which of the following claims about the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> mammalian genes is most likely to be accurate?

choices.label: The <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes are located next to each other on a single chromosome and are organized into an operon.

The <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes may be located on different chromosomes but are activated by the same transcription factor.

The <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes are identical genes since they are activated by the same transcription factor.

The <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes may be located on different chromosomes but with identical operator sequences.

content.answer: The <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes may be located on different chromosomes but are activated by the same transcription factor.
